19
Taphofacies 6 450
451
The taphofacies 6 indicates the most distal environments of the basin (Fig. 6). 452
The facies showed that, despite being located offshore, there might still be sporadic 453
action of return currents caused by storm waves, given the presence of (thin) lenses 454
of sand and some invertebrates typical of shallow water (infaunal lingulids that lived 455
in shoreface). This environment was much less oxygenated, dysaerobic to anoxic, 456
with the occurrence of pyrite. The bioturbation is characterized exclusively by 457
horizontal traces, which indicate a low energy environment. The taphonomic and 458
paleoecologic features demonstrate an association of indigenous taxonomic groups 459
(e.g., Edmondia sp.) with transported species (infaunal lingulids, Orbiculoidea sp., 460
Lingulepis wagoneri). The Edmondia remains are usually articulated and associated 461
to a few disarticulated valves; therefore, it is very difficult to assign an in situ 462
situation for them. Besides being Edmondia individuals shallow-burrower organisms 463
(Runnegar and Newell, 1971), mollusks in general are among the most resistant 464
organisms to taphonomic loss (Kowalewski, 1997). Kotzian and Simões (1997) 465
suggested suggest that this group lived in deep environments, out of direct wave 466
action, what allow them to be considered indigenous, even when occurring as 467
disarticulated valves. These features allow suggesting that they lived below or near 468
the limit of SWB. 469
According Mergl (2001) and Comniskey (2011), the habit of life 470
Orbiculoidea sp. indicates that they lived in shallow waters, and probably isolated 471
bioclasts buried in transitional offshore to offshore sediments are allochthonous. This 472
is possible if considering that when the fossils are found clustered, preserved in 473
coarse sediments, they can be interpreted as grouped for protection against predation, 474
20
or to facilitate reproduction. The occurrence of different ecological guilds (Aberhan, 475
1994) in this taphofacies and different degrees of durability of bioclasts 476
(Kowalewski, 1997) could suggest a temporally condensed section (Simões and 477
Kowalewski, 1998). However, the absence of high fragmentation degree, abrasion, 478
corrosion and bioerosion suggests low turbulence and very short residence time in 479
the TAZ. Therefore, this taphofacies indicates return currents, related to storm 480
events, transporting the animals from shallow waters to the offshore, preserving 481
concentrations generated by obruption deposits of molluscan fauna (Edmondia). 482
483
TAPHOFACIES CONTRIBUTION FOR PALEOECOLOGICAL AND 484
PALEOENVIRONMENTAL INTERPRETATION 485
486
As here demonstrated, the taphonomic signatures coupled with information such 487
as the range of bathymetric habitats and ecological habits of taxonomic groups 488
occurring in the taphofacies can generate secure interpretations, along with the 489
application for paleoenvironmental and paleoecological reconstructions. The presence 490
of fossil associations of animals from different ecological guilds seems to be a purely 491
taphonomic factor (e.g. spatial and vertical transport, time averaging). The fauna of 492
marine invertebrates is always subject to loss of original information due to taphonomic 493
destructive environmental factors that result in the loss of information, shuffled in the 494
fossil record (Behrensmeyer et al., 2000). 495
As noted by Peck et al., (1999) and Bosetti et al., (2012), benthic communities 496
that inhabit cold temperate regions are subject to more inhospitable weather. The result 497
of these changing conditions is creating storms (Brett and Seilacher, 1992) of greater or 498
lesser magnitude. Thus, the benthic fauna suffers from advection caused by transport 499
21
(vertical or lateral spreading) in unconsolidated substrates. Therefore, this may be one 500
explanation for the genesis of taphofacies containing bioclasts taphonomically 501
indigenous/parauthochtonous, of distinct ecological guilds. 502
The use and application of taphofacies also generate more faithful interpretations 503
of in situ fossil findings, like infaunal lingulids, bivalve mollusks and whole trilobite 504
carapaces. Figure 7 shows the paleoenvironmental reconstruction of the studied section, 505
displaying the taxa occurring in the taphofacies here presented, informing the degree of 506
transport (authochtony x allochtony) degree preserved. From this reconstruction it is 507
possible to see more clearly how the organisms were actually distributed and how they 508
are preserved in the fossil record. Each group has its vertical distribution in the basin 509
according to its bathymetric distribution range, as well as paleoenvironmental and 510
paleoecological needs, such as water energy and oxygenation. 511

CONCLUSIONS 513
514
The study taphofacies high latitude siliciclastic environments presented here 515
proved quite accurate for paleoecological and paleoenvironmental interpretations. The 516
six taphofacies recognized here provided sufficient data to show paleoenvironments 517
ranging from offshore to shoreface. The main controlling factors for taphonomic 518
signatures generation were normal and storm waves. In the proximal parts of the basin, 519
the final burial took place at times of increased rates of sedimentation, and owing to the 520
phenomenon of higher magnitude of proximal tempestites too. The TAZ (tafonomically 521
active zone), as well as its post-burial-caused vertical migration, was an important 522
taphonomic agent for the destruction of the original biocoenosis information in these 523
regions of the basin. Studying and understanding this phenomenon is important for it 524
22
shows that the taphonomic bias may be caused by purely ecological strategies in 525
response to environment/sedimentary shifts, and not only by (early) diagenetic factors. 526
Studies on the TAZ of Paleozoic sediments are remarkably rare; when these 527
sedimentary layers are fossil-depleted they tend to be richly bioturbated, and this feature 528
deserves further detailed studies with an integrative, taphonomic-ecological-and 529
environmentally directed, evaluation. 530
In distal regions of the basin the final burial took place when backflow currents 531
caused by storms of greater magnitude occurred, with the inclusion of obruption 532
deposits by decantation of fine offshore sediments. Those currents brought bioclasts 533
from shallow waters, leading to the occurrence of the phenomenon of temporal mixing 534
due to advection and different residence times. The recognition of the habitat range, 535
ecological habits and taphonomic signatures occurring across the taxonomic groups 536
proved to be important for generating data for paleoenvironmental and paleoecological 537
reconstructions through criteria of taphofacies information analysis. 538
